crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN Binding Request)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert udp $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET 3478 (msg:"ET INFO Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN Binding Request)"; content:"|00 01|"; depth:2; content:"|21 12 a4 42|"; distance:2; within:4; reference:url,tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5389; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2016149; rev:3; metadata:created_at 2013_01_04, deployment Perimeter, deployment alert_only, confidence High, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2023_04_24;)

alert tls $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any (msg:"ET INFO TLS Handshake Failure"; flow:established,to_client; dsize:7; content:"|15|"; depth:1; content:"|00 02 02 28|"; distance:2; within:4; fast_pattern; classtype:bad-unknown; sid:2029340; rev:2; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2020_01_30, deployment Perimeter, confidence High, signature_severity Informational, tag Description_Generated_By_Proofpoint_Nexus, updated_at 2020_01_30;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: SURICATA STREAM Packet with invalid timestamp
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp any any -> any any (msg:"SURICATA STREAM Packet with invalid timestamp"; stream-event:pkt_invalid_timestamp; classtype:protocol-command-decode; sid:2210044; rev:2;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: SURICATA STREAM SHUTDOWN RST invalid ack
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp any any -> any any (msg:"SURICATA STREAM SHUTDOWN RST invalid ack"; stream-event:rst_invalid_ack; classtype:protocol-command-decode; sid:2210046; rev:2;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: SSLBL: Malicious JA3 SSL-Client Fingerprint detected (AsyncRAT)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tls any any -> any any (msg:"SSLBL: Malicious JA3 SSL-Client Fingerprint detected (AsyncRAT)"; ja3_hash; content:"fc54e0d16d9764783542f0146a98b300"; reference:url, sslbl.abuse.ch/ja3-fingerprints/fc54e0d16d9764783542f0146a98b300/; sid:906200096; rev:1;)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell scripts attempting to disable scheduled scanning and other parts of Windows Defender ATP or set default actions to allow.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: frack113, elhoim, Tim Shelton (fps, alias support), Swachchhanda Shrawan Poudel, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=Start-Transcript -Path 'C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent\agent_install.log' -Append
Write-Host '=== Booking Agent Setup Started ==='
Write-Host 'Date: ' (Get-Date)
$completionMarker = Join-Path $env:PROGRAMDATA 'booking_agent_done.flag'
$agentExePath = 'C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent\BookingAgent.exe'
$startupLnkPath = 'C:\Users\reception\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\BookingAgent.lnk'
if ((Test-Path $agentExePath) -and (Test-Path $startupLnkPath)) {
    Write-Host [TRUNCATED]; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=caeed360-2039-4616-b0f7-c69d40153266; Path=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\sample.ps1; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

@{ScriptBlockText=Start-Transcript -Path 'C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent\agent_install.log' -Append
Write-Host '=== Booking Agent Setup Started ==='
Write-Host 'Date: ' (Get-Date)
$completionMarker = Join-Path $env:PROGRAMDATA 'booking_agent_done.flag'
$agentExePath = 'C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent\BookingAgent.exe'
$startupLnkPath = 'C:\Users\reception\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\BookingAgent.lnk'
if ((Test-Path $agentExePath) -and (Test-Path $startupLnkPath)) {
    Write-Host [TRUNCATED]; Path=C:\Users\OLLBkBOaVvCI\AppData\Local\Temp\ae24ddd3fd17b680711ec0a3a9916be3.ps1; ScriptBlockId=54c392a5-057b-4762-a5b0-9a6fa7f8ba2f; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with CRLF line terminators

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided PowerShell code appears to be a script designed to install a program called "Booking Agent" on a Windows system. The script begins by creating a log file to document its actions and checks if the agent is already installed or if a setup process is already in progress. If either condition is true, the script exits without making any changes.

The script then creates a "completion marker" file to indicate that the installation process is underway. It performs a network verification by attempting to access a specified URL, which could be a method to check for internet connectivity or the availability of a remote server.

A significant portion of the script involves configuring security settings. It disables real-time monitoring in Windows Defender and adds exclusions for the agent's installation directory and executable. This behavior is highly suspicious as it indicates an attempt to evade detection by security software.

The script validates the download source for the agent component by sending a HEAD request to a specified URL. If the validation fails, it cleans up by removing the completion marker and exits. If successful, it proceeds to download the agent executable, retrying the download a few times if necessary.

Once the download is complete, the script attempts to launch the agent executable. It also creates a startup entry in the Windows Startup folder, ensuring that the agent runs automatically when the user logs in. Additionally, it modifies registry settings to approve the startup entry, which is another indicator of persistence.

Finally, the script restores the security settings by re-enabling real-time monitoring in Windows Defender and concludes the installation process.

Overall, the script exhibits several characteristics typical of malicious software, including the disabling of security features, the creation of persistent startup entries, and the downloading of an executable from a potentially untrusted source.

## Conclusion:
The behavior and functionality of the code strongly suggest that it is designed to install and run potentially harmful software while circumventing security measures. Therefore, it is classified as malicious.

The code initiates logging to a file within `C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent`. It then checks for existing installation files or a completion marker; if found, it terminates. It creates a completion marker file to prevent re-execution. Following this, it attempts to open a URL, which serves as a general network reachability check.

The script proceeds to disable Windows Defender Real-time Monitoring and configures exclusions for the `C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent` directory and `BookingAgent.exe` process. It then performs a HEAD request to `https://bknvrd.com/go/stllift.exe` to validate the download source. If this validation fails, it removes the completion marker and exits.

Next, the script attempts to download a file from `https://bknvrd.com/go/stllift.exe` to `C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent\BookingAgent.exe`. This download is retried up to three times with increasing delays. If all download attempts fail, it removes the completion marker and exits.

Upon successful download, the script executes the `C:\ProgramData\BookingAgent\BookingAgent.exe` file. It then establishes persistence by creating a shortcut for `BookingAgent.exe` in the current user's Startup folder. Additionally, it modifies a specific registry key under `HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\StartupApproved\StartupFolder` to ensure the newly created shortcut is approved for startup. Finally, it re-enables Windows Defender Real-time Monitoring and stops the logging transcript.
